journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A finite element suite for deformation analysis of composite aeroelastic structures subjected to operational aerodynamic loading

article-meta.aff: Division of Mechanical Engineering, Northumbria University, UK

author-notes.corresp: Alireza Maheri, Division of Mechanical Engineering, Northumbria University, Newcastle upon Tyne, UK. Email: alireza.maheri@northumbria.ac.uk

article-meta.issue-title: Includes a special section on Parametric Excitation: Applications in science and engineering

abstract.p: A finite element suite for robust and reliable deformation analysis of aeroelastic composite lifting surfaces is presented. The suite consists of a natural-mode finite element solver, an adaptive mesh generator, an interface for communication with external aerodynamic codes and an auxiliary program for defining material properties. With the aim of reducing the computational time of the finite element analysis within an iterative coupled aero-structure analysis, the aerodynamic and structural characteristics of the aeroelastic composite surface are directly incorporated in the mesh generation procedure. This is realized by utilizing an anisotropic mesh density function. It has been shown that a mesh generated based on the presented theory has significant effect on improving the efficiency and the performance of coupled aero-structure analysis of aeroelastic lifting surfaces.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Aerodynamic lifting surfaces made of fibrous composite materials can be aeroelastically tailored by implanting elastic coupling in their structures. It has been shown that two types of elastic coupling, namely bend-twist and stretch-twist, can have favourable influence on the aerodynamic performance of blades and wings made of unbalanced composite materials.1–5

The interconnection between the topology of an adaptive aerodynamic surface and the aerodynamic load demands an iterative coupled aero-structure analysis, even when the surface is subjected to steady aerodynamic loads.3 In an iterative coupled aero-structure analysis, the effect of the induced deformation on the topology of the lifting surface is taken into account. Correcting the surface topology, its effect on the aerodynamic loading and subsequently the induced deformation will be re-calculated. This sequence repeats until a converged solution is achieved. The fact that even small changes in the topology of an aerodynamic surface could have significant effects on its aerodynamic performance, together with the current deficiencies in the available analytical models for reliable analysis of unbalanced composites with complex geometries, has placed the finite element (FE) techniques to the fore of structural analysis of aeroelastic surfaces. A schematic description of a coupled aero-structure analysis is shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Coupled aero-structure analysis of unbalanced composite lifting surface.

In the design of aeroelastic surfaces, additional complexity arises due to the fact that these structures have dynamic topologies which vary with operating condition. Therefore, the current practice for the topology design of conventional lifting surfaces is no longer applicable to aeroelastic surfaces. Their design is rather a search-based design. Performing a search-based design requires robust and efficient search algorithms and analysis tools.

Running a finite element analysis (FEA) within an iteration loop can be very time consuming. In the case of aeroelastic surfaces, in which the search-based design process requires hundreds of objective evaluations, employing a coupled aero-structure analysis can be extremely time consuming. The new package, consisting of a mesh generator and a FE solver written in FORTRAN, has been specially designed for this purpose.
The following sections describe the strategies adopted in the development of this package, making it a robust and reliable tool for coupled aero-structure analysis of aeroelastic composite surfaces.

sec.title: High-performance element
sec.p: Beam, shell and solid elements have been used in the analysis of anisotropic blades and wings. Using beam elements, a relatively smaller number of elements are required to model the structure, but in-plane and out-of-plane warping must be properly modelled to obtain accurate results. For an anisotropic beam, equations governing the in-plane and out-of-plane warping functions are fully coupled. The beam elements are limited to thin-walled cross-sections and mostly consider only the effect of the out of plane warping. Using solid elements offers a modelling flexibility that no beam or shell element can provide, but in comparison with the shell elements, they need a large number of degrees of freedom (DOF) to model the structure, which is a disadvantage that cannot be ignored in an iterative analysis. A suitable element for FEA of unbalanced thin-walled composite structures should be able to capture the non-classical behaviours of anisotropic structures through its background theory, giving acceptable results with coarse meshes.

For our purpose, flat shell elements are more attractive than the curved shell elements as the time-consuming task of computing the element curvatures is completely avoided in a flat shell formulation. The cost of the stiffness formulation for a flat shell element is much less than that for a curved shell element. Hence, flat shell elements are more suitable for iterative analyses, as the stiffness matrix will have to be evaluated and factorized several times. Many displacement-based isoparametric flat shell elements, which have been successfully implemented in commercial packages, can be found in the literature. However, the performance of none of these shell elements is fully satisfactory for our purpose.

Flat shell elements based on unconventional methods such as mixed, natural-mode and free formulations have also been successfully developed. Amongst them, TRIangular Composite6 (TRIC) is a 3-node shear-deformable triangular composite flat shell element based on natural-mode formulation. Its kinematics is expressed by 6 rigid-body and 12 natural straining modes of deformation. Straining modes represent axial straining, symmetrical and anti-symmetrical bending, transverse shearing and azimuth rotation modes. Inclusion of the transverse shear deformations in the formulation eliminates shear-locking phenomena based on a first-order shear deformable beam theory. A simple matrix operation transforms the elemental stiffness matrix from natural to global system of coordinates. It has been shown that it is an accurate and reliable element for the analysis of thin and moderately thick anisotropic shell structures, even when using coarse meshes.6–9 TRIC has been selected for the FE solver part of the package as it is of the desired robustness, accuracy and efficiency and fulfils all the above-mentioned requirements.

sec.title: Adaptive mesh
sec.p:
In view of the earlier discussion regarding the requirement of updating the mesh in each iteration and also the fact that mesh quality becomes vital when the structure is analysed within an iteration loop, a suitable mesh generator to be used in an iterative coupled aero-structure analysis should fulfil the following requirements.
It must account for the topology changes, automatically, in each iteration.
It must discretise the domain, automatically, in each iteration.
It must update the nodal loading, automatically, in each iteration.
It should be fast.
It should produce high-quality meshes.

The first three requirements lead one to take an adaptive mesh generation approach. The term adaptive meshing here, in contrast to its usage for expressing the automatic re-meshing of a domain in time marching problems with moving boundaries, or in static problems with highly deformable structures, refers to the automatic updating of the mesh in each iteration of a coupled aero-structure analysis. The third requirement also suggests an in-line mesh generator, which is located between the plugged-in aerodynamic and the FE solvers (Figure 2). Figure 2.
In-line adaptive mesh generator.

When using an interactive CAD system, a twisted tapered blade/wing with variable chord and aerofoil distributions can be categorized as an object with a relatively complicated geometry. Modelling of such an object may need significant user effort and time. However, the geometry and topology of a wing or blade (chord, pre-twist, aerofoil distribution and aerofoil contours together with sizes and defining angles) can be easily defined in small flat files. These files can be used to automatically construct the model with negligible computational time compared to that required for the FE solver. In an in-line mesh generation approach, the modelling part of the FEA is treated as part of mesh generation taking place prior to domain discretisation.

Regarding the automated load updating, it is required to develop an interface capable of communicating with the aerodynamic solver, which is plugged into the package. The interface extracts data and calculates the nodal external forces. Depending on the method employed by the aerodynamic solver for predicting the aerodynamic forces, the results to be extracted by the interface can be in the form of load per unit span or load per unit area. When the aerodynamic solver produces aerodynamic load per unit span, e.g. when using blade-element-momentum theory (BEMT) method for wind turbine blades, the interface must distribute the load over the shell area and then convert it to nodal forces. Provided load per unit area, e.g. in the case of the use of control-volume-based computational fluid dynamics (CFD) or panel methods for an aircraft wing, the interface just needs to convert it to nodal forces.

With reference to requirements 4 and 5 above, a semi-automatic mesh generation approach has been adopted, in which discretization is based on a mesh density function under the influence of the variation of the physics of the problem as well as geometrical parameters. Adopting this approach, the FEA box in Figure 1 can be detailed as illustrated in Figure 3. Figure 3.
FEA box of Figure 1 in details.

sec.title: Discretization strategy
sec.p:
Comparing to shell and webs, the contribution of other components of a wing/blade in carrying the aerodynamic loads can be neglected. Therefore, only shell and webs are required to be discretized for an FEA aimed at deformation prediction. To discretize a wing/blade domain τ∈ℜ3, first it is divided and mapped onto a set of two-dimensional (2D) sub-domains τ'∈ℜ2 (τ'=τshell '∪∑l=1 nwebτwebl '). Then, discretization takes place over the new sub-domains and finally the discretized 2D domains are transformed back into the 3D domain. Let a 2D domain in the (ξ,η) plane be considered for discretization. Here, the mesh size at a general point (ξ0,η0) is defined as the distance between the sides of the triangle surrounding the point along the two directions of ξ and η (δ and λ in Figure 4(a)). The mesh size is assumed to be proportional to the inverse of a mesh density function ρ(ξ,η), in a directional sense, as follows: (1) (2) Figure 4.
(a) Mesh size definition and (b) special case of parallel stripes ρηξ=0.

It can be easily shown that: (3) and (4) where nζ, Ξ, nη and H are the numbers of divisions and the total length of the numerical domain along ξ and η directions at locations η0 and ξ0, and (ρ¯ξ)i=∫0 δ(∂ρ/∂ξ)η=constdξ and (ρ¯η)i=∫0 λ(∂ρ/∂η)ξ=constdη the mean values of the mesh density over δi and λj along ξ and η directions, respectively. Generally, given a mesh density function, equations (3) and (4) can be used for the determination of the mesh size over the entire domain. In the special case ∂(∂ρ/∂η)/∂ξ=0, when the variation of mesh density along η is independent of ξ, nodes will be located on lines parallel to ξ axis, as shown in Figure 4(b). It should be noted that the mesh density is not an isotropic function and therefore ρξη≠ρηξ. Imposing this condition to the mesh density function does not affect the mesh efficiency if the physical aspects of the problem along η do not vary at different ξ locations. In fact, this is the case where chord and span of wing/blade are taken as the two directions in defining the mesh density function.

Applying this simplification on the mesh density function yields to the following results:
At a location η=ηj, the mesh sizes δi along ξ are equal to the distance between two adjacent nodes.
The mesh sizes λj along η are equal to the distance between two adjacent nodes, independent of the ξi location.

The chief advantage of utilizing this approach in mesh generation (discretization into parallel stripes) is that one can directly establish the directional mesh densities ρξ(ξ,η) and ρη(η) without any need for direct involvement of the mesh density ρ(ξ,η) itself.
Now, given a mesh density function in which ∂ρη∂ξ=0, equations (3) and (4), in their new forms, can be used to directly determine the nodes’ locations (ξi,ηj) as follows: (5) (6)

By selecting the coordinates ξ and η along the chord axis x and span axis y, equations (5) and (6) can be re-written as: (7) (8) where nc and ns are the numbers of chord-wise and span-wise divisions in the shell domain, ρc and ρs the chord-wise and span-wise mesh densities, respectively, s the span length and cj the chord length at span location j. Equations (7) and (8) give the x- and y-coordinates of the nodes in the sub-domain τshell ' (Figure 5). Figure 5.
Numerical 2D domains.

By selecting coordinates ξandη along the normal axis zand span axisy, equation (5) can be re-written as: (9) which gives the z-coordinates of the nodes in τwebl ' domain (Figure 4). In the above equation, nwebl is the number of divisions in the lthweb domain, ρwebl the mesh density along z and hl the web height at span location yj.

The following parameters affect the efficiency of a mesh when predicting the deformation, and therefore have been considered in establishing the mesh density functions:
Distributions of the dominant internal force and the effective stiffness in order to locate more deformable parts of the aeroelastic surface, avoiding over-refinement of regions which are less effective in deformation.
The surface topological variations in order to identify the high curvature regions, as required for mapping a curved structure with flat elements.
Distribution of external force as required for accurately calculating nodal forces when using coarse meshes.

sec.title: Span-wise mesh density ρs
sec.p: Since normally there is no particular region along the span of a blade/wing where the aerodynamic forces have high concentrations, there is no need to include the effect of the external forces in the span-wise mesh density. Also, typically, the span-wise topological variations of a blade/wing (i.e. pre-twist, chord and aerofoil distributions) occur smoothly and therefore, since span is much longer than the chord, by generating proper elements (λ ~δ), there is always enough span-wise stripes to accurately capture the topological variations. Eliminating the effect of the external forces and the topological variations along the span leaves the dominant internal force and effective stiffness distributions as the only parameters that directly affect the span-wise mesh size. Contribution of the dominant internal force and the effective stiffness in the mesh size can be addressed by deformability density ρdef s, a dimensionless parameter bounded between 0 and 1, and defined as follows: (10) where F is the dominant internal force and Keff the effective stiffness, relating the dominant internal force to the dominant induced deformation. Span-wise mesh density ρs is defined as follows: (11)

Span-wise regulating exponent rs∈[0,1] in the above equation indicates the level of dependency of the span-wise mesh density on the deformability density ρdef s. It can be either set to zero to produce a uniform span-wise mesh or can be automatically manipulated to avoid generating improper elements as explained below. Figure 6 shows two critical stripes of domain τshell ' of a wing/blade with small taper angle. Angles α and β have the potential of being the smallest angles in the entire mesh. To avoid generating improper triangles with angles smaller than a permissible smallest angle ɛ, the following criteria must be satisfied. (12) and (13) Figure 6.
Critical angles in 2D numerical domain.
Regulating exponent rs affects the ratio of (ρs)min/(ρs)max and therefore the ratio of λmin/λmax as a control on the smallest angle of the triangular mesh.

sec.title: Chord-wise mesh density ρc
sec.p: In cases when no chord-wise shape change is expected (i.e. inner fillers or the stiffeners in a blade/wing prevent the aerofoil shape from change), the deformability is not an affecting parameter in chord direction. This leaves the aerofoil curvature and the pressure distribution, as an indicator to the chord-wise external forces, as the two parameters needed to be considered in constructing the chord-wise mesh density.

In the regions of high curvature, the mesh must be fine enough to be able to follow the curvature. The contribution of the curvature on the chord-wise mesh size can be addressed by curvature density ρκ c, defined as: (14)
in which all κ's are absolute values of aerofoil curvature.10

In high-pressure regions, there should be enough nodes in order to apply the external aerodynamic load on the blade as accurately as possible. Chord-wise force density ρF c, defined by the following equation, represents the intensity of the pressure on the aerofoil.10 (15) in which CP indicates the absolute pressure coefficient.

Another parameter which is introduced and used in constructing the chord-wise mesh density function is the direction factor. Direction factor fD identifies those parts of the chord that are less sensitive to mesh refinement. The concept of direction factor can be explained by the following example. The thin-walled box beam shown in Figure 7 is subjected to a transverse tip load and is considered to be analysed for deformation using TRIC elements. The initial mesh is a coarse mesh with 1×1×20 number of equal spacing divisions along b, h and l, respectively. Carrying out a step-by-step directional mesh refinement, it can be observed that mesh refinement along the x-direction does not improve the results (Figure 8(a)), whilst mesh refinement along z-direction has significant influence on the convergence rate of the results, as shown in Figure 8(b). Based on this observation, it can be argued that the mesh efficiency also depends on the direction of elements relative to the direction of dominant internal force. Since the main internal force in a blade/wing is the bending moment, direction factor is defined based on the angle between the normal vector to the blade surface and the bending moment vector. It should have a minimum value when the two vectors are perpendicular to each other and a maximum value when they are parallel. Here, the direction factor is defined as: (16) where MEB and MFB are the edge- and flap-wise bending moments, respectively, and z(x) stands for the aerofoil contour. Figure 7.
Cantilever box beam subjected to transverse tip load. Figure 8.
Step-by-step directional mesh refinement. (a) Mesh refinement along x-direction and (b) mesh refinement along z-direction.

Equation (17) gives the chord-wise mesh density function, in which the chord-wise force density ρF c and curvature density ρκ c are combined in a weighted sense. The result is multiplied by the direction factor to flatten those parts of the chord less sensitive to mesh refinement. Then, it is regulated using chord-wise regulating exponent rc. (17) where rF∈[0,1] is the weighting factor representing the contribution of the force density on the mesh density. Chord-wise regulating exponent rc∈[0,1] is used so as to prevent the generation of improper elements by limiting the ratio of (ρc)min/(ρc)max or equivalently δmin/δmax. Very small values for δmin/δmax in a stripe lead to the generation of improper elements regardless of the value of λ. Applying equations (12) and (13) to a single stripe gives the following criterion for the ratio δmin/δmax: (18) which can be automatically manipulated by applying the regulating exponent rc to the chord-wise mesh density.

sec.title: Web mesh density ρwebl
sec.p: Since the web heights are relatively short, applying a variable mesh density along web height hardly leads to generation of a variable size mesh. Therefore, discretization of the webs is based on a uniform mesh size (equivalent to ρweb=1). Selecting a mesh size of γ with the order of δ at that web location avoids generating improper elements in the webs.

sec.title: Nodal coordinates
sec.p:
Having determined the directional mesh densities, there are two ways to use equations (7) to (9) for finding the nodal coordinates:
Given the number of divisions and solve the equation for nodes’ coordinates.
Given one node location, then the equation can be solved for other nodes’ coordinates.

Using equation (17) and having calculated the chord-wise mesh density ρc, equation (7) can be used to calculate the chord-wise nodal coordinates at each span location for a given number of chord-wise divisions nc.

On the other hand, since the coarsest span-wise mesh always occurs at the tip of the wing/blade, selecting λ1=(δmin)1/tanɛ will automatically satisfy the criterion of equation (12) and only the criterion of equation (13) needs to be satisfied through manipulation of rs. By this, having calculated the span-wise mesh density ρs by equation (11), and having known λ1 (and therefore y1), equation (8) can be used to calculate the span-wise nodal coordinates.

After obtaining nodal x- and y-coordinates in 2D domain of τshell ', aerofoil contour can be used to find the z-coordinate of each node. The following transformation maps the sub-domains τshell ' and τwebl ' back to τ. (19)
In the above equations, β0 is pre-twist angle and x0 the pre-twist axis.

sec.title: Nodal loading
sec.p: Since the chord-wise mesh density depends on the chord-wise force density ρF c, the mesh will be always denser in regions with sharper pressure variations. By selecting a proper number of divisions along the chord of the surface, the number of divisions along the chord will be large enough to capture the chord-wise variation of the aerodynamic pressure. As mentioned earlier, by employing a permissible minimum angle ɛ in mesh generation, the element size in the span direction will be of the same order of magnitude as the element size in the chord direction. Hence, the number of divisions along the span of wing/blade will be always large enough to capture the span-wise variation of the aerodynamic load applied on wing/blade.

Since applied forces smoothly vary within element length scales along both chord and span directions, and since TRIC element has no internal nodes, a node-by-node lumping method is used to calculate the nodal forces. Each node is assigned a tributary region around it that extends halfway to adjacent nodes (Figure 9). The force contribution of this tributary region is directly assigned to the node. The body force due to the weight and the centrifugal force applied on node (i,j)can be determined by (20) in which, respectively, w and fI are the weight and the inertia force per unit area of the lifting surface and ΔsΔy (Δy=(yj+1-yj-1)/2, Δs=Δx2+Δz2, Δx=(xi+1-xi-1)/2 at yj, Δz=(zi+1-zi-1)/2 at yj) is the tributary region of node (i,j). Here, the coordinate s is defined along the shell contour as well as the webs, if any. Figure 9.
Nodal loading and tributary region.

Depending on the type of the aerodynamic solver plugged into the FE suite, two approaches are taken to calculate the contribution of the aerodynamic forces on the nodal loading. The aerodynamic forces can be obtained either by a 3D CFD-based analysis in which the force per unit area of the blade surface (pressure) is known or by using BEMT-based analysis in which the equivalent concentrated forces per unit length of span is calculated. BEMT is widely used for predicting the aerodynamic performance of rotors. BEMT employs 2D lift and drag coefficients obtained by wind tunnel tests corrected by taking into account the finite length and rotation corrections. In the case of plugging a CFD-based aerodynamic solver, the nodal force due to the aerodynamic pressure applied on node (i,j), F can be determined by (21) in which, respectively, p is the pressure distribution over the node tributary region and e∧n the global unit vector normal to the surface at the node location. Here, the coordinate s is defined along the shell contour.

If experimental data are used, the aerodynamic force distribution is not known. In this case, the pressure distribution can be used as a measure for the force distribution in order to improve the accuracy of nodal loading. By discretising the lifting surfaces into parallel stripes, the process of loading a 3D wing/blade is replaced by loading a set of 2D aerofoils. The aerodynamic nodal forces Fx and Fz at a span location can be expressed in terms of corrected 2D experimental aerodynamic lift and drag coefficients (CL and CD) as follows: (22)

In the above set of equations, c is the aerofoil chord length, α the angle of attack, 12ρV2 for the dynamic pressure and ΔxΔy the projected surface area corresponding to the node. Normalized distributed forces wx and wz are defined as (23) (24) in which dfP/dx is the distributed pressure force f^Pper unit length of chord and c/fP the normalization factor.

To have equivalent actual and discretized force systems, the nodal forces must produce the same amount of pitching moment as the aerodynamic force does. The difference between the actual pitching moment and that due to the discretized nodal forces (based on pressure distribution), ΔMc/4, must be distributed on the nodes as concentrated couples of My given by: (25) in which n=nc is the number of nodes on the blade/wing surface at the span location of y and (26) where (27) and x*=x/c and z*=z/c.
Quantities (1/2)ρV2,c, α,CL and CD are given at the span location of y=yj, whilst wx and wz are given at the chord location of x=xi.

For twisted blades/wings, each stripe has its own aerofoil axes x and z. By selecting the aerofoil axes at location of zero pre-twist as global axes X and Z, global nodal forces can be determined through the following transformation. (28)

sec.title: Material definition
sec.p: Material definition takes place via an auxiliary program prior to commencing the FEA. This program gets the location of different material patches and their mechanical properties and generates two sets of files. The first set includes the locations of different materials and it is required for mesh adjustment and elemental material indexing. The second set includes material files (0th, 1st and 2nd moments of transformed transverse shear stiffness and transformed reduced stiffness matrices over the laminate thickness) as required for generating the stiffness matrix.6

sec.title: FE suite overall performance
sec.p: In this section, the performance of the FE suite is shown by plugging in a BEMT-based rotor aerodynamic code and carrying out a case study on coupled aero-structure analysis of wind turbine adaptive blades. The rotor aerodynamic code employs the updated blade topology calculated by the FE suite to calculate the aerodynamic load on the blade as well as the rotor mechanical power. The studied adaptive blade has similar aerofoil and chord distributions as those of the blades of 300-kW stall-regulated AWT27 wind turbines but with a different pre-twist distribution. More details on the aerofoil distribution and blade geometry can be found in the study of Maheri et al.2 The skin of the adaptive blades is made of graphite/epoxy with 20 degrees off-axis mirror layup with a constant thickness of 10 mm through span. Mechanical properties of the blade skin are E1=142, E2=E3=9.8, G12=G13=6.14 and G23=4.83GPa; ν12=ν13=0.50 and ν23=0.42.

Running the coupled aero-structure analysis with a zero initial induced twist, it was observed that depending on the wind turbine operating condition, it takes 8–12 iterations to achieve a solution satisfying the convergence criterion of |Pnew-Pold|Pold≤4%. Figures 10 to 12 show the results of the first seven iterations of coupled aero-structure analysis of this wind turbine operating at a steady wind speed of 10 m/s, rotor speed of 53.3 r/min and zero rotor yaw angle. Figure 10.
Span-wise distribution of the torsional-induced deformation at zero blade azimuth angle. Figure 11.
Span-wise distribution of total aerodynamic force at zero blade azimuth angle. Figure 12.
Aerodynamic performance of the wind turbine utilizing adaptive blades.

sec.title: Mesh efficiency
sec.p: In order to investigate the effect of different parameters in directional mesh densities given by equations (11) and (17), the adaptive bend-twist wind turbine blade of section ‘FE suite overall performance’ was analysed. Here, the predicted induced twist at the tip of the blade βTip has been considered for mesh convergence study. It should be mentioned that in order to compare the performance of the various mesh configurations, the blade aerodynamic loading must be identical for all cases. Therefore, the induced twist predicted at the end of the first iteration was captured as the result (Figures 10 and 11). These results are obviously different from the final results of a completed coupled aero-structure.

Table 1 shows different mesh configurations used in the FEA of this blade. In all cases, chord-wise regulating exponent rc, and where applied, span-wise regulating exponent rs have been automatically manipulated to prevent generation of improper elements. Table 1.
Various mesh configurations.
Mesh configuration Aerofoil curvature Chord-wise force density Direction factor Deformability Span-wise mesh density Chord-wise mesh density
1 Yes Noa Nob Noc ρs=1 ρc=[ρκ c]rc
2 Yes Yesd Nob Noc ρs=1 ρc=[rFρF c+(1-rF)ρκ c]rc
3 Yes Yesd Yes Noc ρs=1 ρc=[(rFρF c+(1-rF)ρκ c)fD]rc
4 Yes Yesd Yes Yes ρs=[ρdef s]rs ρc=[(rFρF c+(1-rF)ρκ c)fD]rc
a
rF=0; chord-wise mesh size based only on the aerofoil curvature. b
fD=1; chord-wise mesh size based only on the aerofoil curvature and pressure distribution. c
rs=0; theoretically uniform span-wise mesh size (constraints are applied on span-wise mesh size to prevent generation of improper elements). d
rF=0.5.

Figure 13 shows the results of mesh refinement towards converged solutions by employing different mesh configurations. According to these results, it can be observed that different mesh configurations lead to different convergence rates. The slowest convergence rate belongs to mesh configuration 1 in which the blade domain has been solely discretized based on the geometry of the blade. In this case, the only parameter affecting the chord-wise mesh density is the aerofoil curvature. This impacts the accuracy of nodal loading too, leading to convergence at a different value. Considering the force density causes gathering of nodes in high-pressure regions of the aerofoil. Therefore, the nodal loading can be calculated more accurately. Comparing the mesh refinement behaviour of mesh configuration 1 to that of mesh configurations 2–4, in which the force density has been considered in the mesh density, evidently both convergence rate and the accuracy of the results significantly improve. The effect of employing the force density on the improvement of the convergence rate is more evident in coarser meshes with smaller numbers of chord-wise increments. Figure 13.
Effect of different parameters on the accuracy and convergence rate.

Figure 14 shows the effect of chord-wise force density on node location. One can observe that when applying force density, the nodes have been shifted towards the leading edge on the upper surface, where the pressure coefficient has its higher values. Figure 14.
Effect of chord-wise external force distribution on node location.

The effect of direction factor fD on the mesh efficiency can be demonstrated by comparing the convergence rates corresponding to mesh configurations 2 and 3 in Figure 15, which is a regeneration of Figure 13. In the case of mesh configuration 2, where fD does not contribute in mesh sizing, to obtain a solution within the margin of 2% of the converged solution 0.99≤βTip/(βTip)converged≤1.01, about 13,000 DOF are required. On the other hand, when the concept of direction factor as well as force and curvature densities is used in mesh creation, the required number of DOF for entering the convergence margin is approximately 9000. This shows a reduction of about 30% in the number of DOF. Figure 15.
Effect of different parameters on the accuracy and convergence rate.

Figure 16 shows the normalized chord-wise node locations, with and without the contribution of direction factor to the mesh density. One can observe that due to the effect of fD, the nodes become closer on the upper surface towards the trailing edge and on the lower surface towards the leading edge. This is due to the condition that fD has higher values in these regions. Figure 16.
Node locations with and without applying direction factor.

Figure 15 also shows the effect of deformability density ρdef s on the mesh efficiency. In this case study, flap bending moment and the induced twist play the role of the dominant internal force and induced deformation, respectively. These two parameters can be correlated by the following equation.11 (29)

In this study, the deformability density has been calculated as (30) in which the span-wise distribution of ∂β/∂y has been calculated based on the results of the FEA of the blade from last iteration in mesh refinement process. According to Figure 15, when the effect of the deformability of the structure is taken into account, the required DOF for entering the convergence margin reduces to less than 7000.

sec.title: TRIC performance
sec.p: Formulation of elements based on natural-mode method, like TRIC element, has the advantage of analytically computing the elemental stiffness matrix, whilst no numerical matrix inversion or integration is involved. Therefore, the stiffness computation is faster than stiffness computation of conventional isoparametric elements. Also, since the element deformation is based on the natural straining modes, the solution converges rapidly and the accuracy is good even when employing coarse meshes.

The accuracy and robustness of TRIC element have been proved through a variety of standard benchmark plate and shell problems.6–9 In this study, the accuracy of TRIC element in deformation analysis of unbalanced composite shells is investigated. The box beam shown in Figure 17 has been widely used as a benchmark for validation of theories and computational analyses of bend-twist closed thin-walled beams. Figures 18 and 19, comparing the induced twist obtained using TRIC element with the experimental data in the study of Chandra et al.,12 demonstrate the reliability of TRIC element in predicting induced deformation in unbalanced thin-walled beams. Figure 17.
Unbalanced composite box beam. Figure 18.
Induced twist due to bend-twist coupling (layup 1). Figure 19.
Induced twist due to bend-twist coupling (layup 2).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: High-fidelity and robust prediction of induced deformation in aeroelastic lifting surfaces are achieved by implementing a natural-mode triangular shell element in the FE solver and including the aerodynamic and structural characteristics of the aeroelastic structure in mesh generation procedure. The semi-automatic adaptive mesh generator is employed as an in-line discretizer and as a topology and load updater in coupled aero-structure analysis of twisted blades and wings with several webs, variable aerofoil distribution and different material patches. The mesh size depends on the aerodynamic and structural characteristics of the blade along chord and span directions as well as the topological characteristics. Mesh distribution is controlled through the number of chord-wise divisions and also five other parameters of span-wise regulating exponent (which directly affects the span-wise divisions), chord-wise regulating exponent, allowable minimum angle, force density weighting factor and the option of applying the direction factor (which affect the chord-wise mesh size directly and span-wise mesh size indirectly).

Since the domain discretization based on the presented theory includes the physics of the problem, more efficient meshes are produced. Considering force density in mesh generation improves the accuracy of the nodal loading when using coarse meshes and consequently increases the overall accuracy of the aero-structure analysis. Applying direction factor reduces the number of required DOF and taking into account the deformability of the blade significantly improves the convergence rate. In an iterative coupled-aero-structure analysis, where the required time for FEA of an unbalanced composite aerodynamic structure can have a considerable contribution to the overall computational time, such a reduction in the number of DOF can have a significant effect on its efficiency and performance.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
